forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Kadyrov remains formally in office through May 31, 2025, continuing limited public appearances or statements while Moscow defers any formal change until later.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Within May, credible outlets report that Kadyrov resigns and the Kremlin appoints an acting head; or he is dismissed by presidential decree; or he dies/becomes incapacitated and an acting head is named—any of which occur before June 1, 2025.
forecast.rationale:
Status quo inertia is strong, especially with only ~19 days left. Although Kadyrov publicly said on May 6 he wants to step down (per The Moscow Times), he has floated leaving before and stayed. The Kremlin typically choreographs Chechen leadership changes carefully given security/stability concerns and Kadyrov’s role. Immediate family successors (notably his 17-year-old son Adam and 26-year-old daughter Aishat) are likely ineligible to be formal head due to age requirements, suggesting any transition would require an interim figure, which Moscow may prefer to time deliberately rather than abruptly.

That said, the short-term hazard is materially above a generic baseline because: (1) persistent, multi‑source reporting of serious health issues (e.g., pancreatic/kidney problems) increases the risk of sudden incapacity; (2) visible succession‑prep signals (rapid promotions for Adam; Aishat in senior government role) indicate planning for an eventual handover; and (3) Kadyrov’s own statement about wanting to step down could foreshadow a negotiated exit. A Kremlin-managed resignation with immediate appointment of an acting head can be executed quickly if needed.

Why not higher: Only ~19 days remain; previous episodes of health rumors and step‑down hints did not culminate in departure; Moscow may prefer continuity during ongoing federal reshuffles and wartime pressures. Why not lower: Multiple plausible triggers (health, resignation accepted, dismissal) exist, and the public step‑down signal plus succession moves elevate near‑term odds above a pure status‑quo base rate.

What would move me up: Credible reports of acute hospitalization/ICU or nonattendance at key meetings; Kremlin personnel groundwork (e.g., leaks about an acting head); state media framing legacy pieces; sudden travel to Moscow/abroad for treatment. What would move me down: Fresh, credible footage of Kadyrov in routine meetings with Kremlin principals; explicit Kremlin denials paired with new appointments reaffirming his tenure; indications that any transition is slated for a later window.
